section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Master the building blocks of every Python program by learning how to create, name, and use variables to store and manipulate data. You will explore Python’s core data types—numbers, text, and Boolean values—and practice converting between them so you can handle real-world information in your code.
learning_objectives: Declare and assign at least five variables with legal, descriptive names following PEP 8 style.
Predict and verify the data type of any literal or variable using type() with 100 % accuracy on a 10-question quiz.
Convert between int, float, str, and bool types without raising errors in three scaffolded coding drills.
Debug and fix NameError and TypeError messages in provided buggy scripts within 2 minutes each.

lessons.lesson_objective: Write at least four valid variable assignments that follow Python naming rules and PEP 8 conventions.

exercises.exercise_instructions: 1. Open the file broken_names.py. 2. Rename each variable so it obeys Python rules and PEP 8. 3. Run the script and confirm it prints four lines without syntax errors.
1. Create a new script my_day.py. 2. Create variables: wake_up_time (int), breakfast_calories (float), is_weekend (bool), main_task (str). 3. Print all four variables on one line using an f-string.

lessons.lesson_objective: Perform accurate arithmetic calculations using int and float types and explain the result's type.

exercises.exercise_instructions: 1. Create variables: price_item1 = 19.99, price_item2 = 7.49, quantity1 = 3, quantity2 = 2. 2. Compute total cost as a float. 3. Compute total_items as an int. 4. Print both results with descriptive labels.

1. Prompt the user for total_cost (float) and num_friends (int). 2. Calculate cost_per_friend using true division. 3. Calculate whole_pizzas_needed using floor division assuming 8 slices per pizza. 4. Display both values rounded to two decimals.

lessons.lesson_objective: Construct new strings by concatenating, repeating, and formatting literals and variables.

exercises.exercise_instructions: 1. Create variables: movie = 'Python Unleashed', tickets = 4, price_per_ticket = 9.5. 2. Build an f-string that outputs: 'Movie: Python Unleashed, Total: $38.0'. 3. Print the length of the string.
1. Ask the user for a single word. 2. Print the word surrounded by a border of asterisks that is 4 characters longer than the word. 3. Use string multiplication to create the border.

lessons.lesson_objective: Evaluate at least three Boolean expressions that combine comparisons and logical operators.

exercises.exercise_instructions: 1. Input age (int) and has_ticket (str: 'yes'/'no'). 2. Convert has_ticket to Boolean. 3. Print True if age >= 18 and has_ticket is True, otherwise False.
1. Input a year (int). 2. Compute is_leap = year % 4 == 0 and (year % 100 != 0 or year % 400 == 0). 3. Print is_leap.

lessons.lesson_objective: Convert user input strings to the correct numeric or Boolean type and handle conversion errors.

exercises.exercise_instructions: 1. Prompt for Celsius as a string. 2. Convert to float. 3. Compute Fahrenheit and print one decimal place using an f-string. 4. Wrap conversion in try/except to catch ValueError and print 'Invalid number'.
1. Ask three yes/no questions returning 'yes' or 'no'. 2. Convert answers to Boolean. 3. Print the number of True answers using simple addition.
1. Open quiz.py. 2. Complete 10 fill-in-the-blank questions on variable names, types, and conversions. 3. Run the script to auto-grade; aim for 10/10.
